title: Thursday, 11th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

So ....... let's ignore the vacant, amoral, grinning publicist and move onto the several thousand retail trading statements we'll have to cover this morning.

AAAA bonjour !

rwl @BE - What wrong with Chatham House . Prey tell :)

Part 194 in the slow death of M&S?

Severe reaction to not terribly exciting news.

(@RWL: what I meant is, what's said on Channel 5 stays on Channel 5. https://www.chatha...chatham-house-rule )

Isn't in the case that the food side is now rotting?

PM11:07am

Or showing signs of going stale?

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Not really. Food LFL down 0.4%, which seems to have made a lot of headlines.

BE11:08am

But the consensus was for down 1%, so it's a bad excuse for the share price weakness.

PM11:08am

hmm

11:08 am
BE11:09am

We've also got clothing and home slightly better than a weak consensus, at down 2.8 per cent vs down 3% expected.

Pseudonym @Fletch If he has a secret goal then who knows if he has have achieved that?
gh But we have Paddy Power tumbling for the second day! Surely Morgan Stanley's fault?
PM11:09am

So is this just a market-wide 'sell shops, all shops' theme?

BE11:09am

Kind of. What we do have is the -- not terribly surprising -- news that M&S had to wear a bit of pain on margins.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

And while there's no explicit change on guidance, the tone of continuing to rejig the offer -- particularly in food -- is a strong hint that forecasts have to come back towards the bottom of the range.

dfd I understand Tesco and M&S being hit, but don't understand Card Factory, which still seems to be a licence to print money.
BE11:11am

Barclays can summarise here.

BE11:11am

The company described 3Q as “a mixed quarter as better Christmas trading in both businesses going some way to offset a weak clothing market in October and ongoing underperformance in our Food like-for-like sales”.

· In the Food business, “ongoing trading pressures continued in the lead up to Christmas as consumer spending and choices reflected tighter budgets. Price investment before Christmas and a strong performance from seasonal lines helped late trading”.

· In the Clothing & Home business, M&S continued with its strategy of “restoring price integrity and improving everyday value”. It “held its full price stance in a very promotional market and did not participate in Black Friday”. However it commented the weak October meant it carried more stock into the December sale.

chopper bear m&s shoud just ditch the clothing business
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @PseudonymI am just thinking of his financial background and links to the City.
11:12 am
BE11:12am

· International revenue was down -9.8% (vs our estimate of -10%) due to the planned closure of owned stores in loss-making markets. However, in retained owned and franchise markets, constant currency revenue increased 6.5%.

BE11:12am

There is no change to the company’s guidance for FY17/18. However ...

BE11:13am

... the “further changes” to the food offer suggest that gross margin may be towards the lower end of the guided range ....

11:12 am
BE11:13am

.... (-75 to -125bps) and the additional stock carried into the sale may also put some downwards pressure on Clothing & Home gross margin (guidance +25-75bps).

PM11:13am

Apparently Steve Rowe was really downbeat on the conference call

PM11:14am

A line from Stifel

11:13 am

BE11:14am

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Whole world is fragile and volatile I guess

BBOC I had an M&S Prawn mayo sandwich on Tuesday. It was truly appalling.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Adding more Card Factory to my portfolio later - when the dust settles.
BE11:15am

Anyway, the selloff this morning seems to be on no particular change to consensus .....

Delta1_ETF Any BOO commentary on BOOHOO? tx
Pseudonym Is a prawn mayo sandwich ever anything other than appalling?
BE11:16am

.... so I guess must be on Rowe's downbeat-ness. Which is a touch weird, because M&S should be priced either as a cash cow (still +10 per cent free cashflow yield, remarkably) or a longer term turnaround play.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Have Morgan Stanley.

Digi Master Morning
FATDAZ @Psuedo introduced in MKs in 1981 I saw on the box last night
BE11:17am

The statement makes clear that full year guidance remains unchanged, so we would not anticipate much change in consensus earnings estimates today.
According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently forecasting that M&S will make underlying Pre Tax Profits of £581m in FY 2017/18 (giving EPS of 28.2p)
- We would contend, however, that the M&S investment case is not really
centred around short term earnings performance. Rather it is about the 5 year transformation program announced in November and what that may, or may not, mean for consensus forecasts for FY 2018/19. Today's short statement provides no new information on this.
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, M&S is trading on 11.3x Cal 2018 earnings, 5.5x EBITDA with a 5.9% dividend yield. This compares with a UK general retail sector trading on 13.1x, 8.2x and 4.0%
respectively

sprout maybe it was a clue when I could still buy an M&S turkey on Xmas eve, when everyone else's was rancid or sold out.
BE11:17am

And Santander, going through the detail on food.

Pseudonym Blimey are you all eating PMS?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

[E]mbedded within the trends is a Food business (55% of group revs), which was once a very consistent outperformer and solid cash cow, but is today very challenged and significantly underperforming the market, despite substantial price investments (c250 lines).
What is more, in a C&H market where growth is increasingly bifurcating to the benefit of online, M&S, already under-indexed in the channel, underperforms. Management states that channel bifurcation is less severe than for the overall market (perhaps given their customer demographics?). Even so, despite substantial investment in the Donnington .com distribution centre
over recent years, the operation is still suffering fulfilment constraints and .com growth is meagre.

BE11:19am

As such, while 3Q may have been reasonable versus conservative market expectations, the bigger and longer-term picture, within the context of both the Food and C&H sectors, is underwhelming and the growth outlook negative.

BE11:19am

Feels like a long, long time since we did the argument that M&S should spin off Simply Food to put it on a Whole Foods rating.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

For one thing, the phrase "Whole Foods rating" doesn't mean the same thing any more.

BE11:20am

Anyway, that's M&S.

Well ... why would someone own Card Factory shares? It's not for the exciting prospect of growth in the greetings card market, unless we're assuming that people will have more birthdays in future.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

It's for the divi.

sprout why is CF particularly hit by FX? Pulp prices?
Nately @sprout - Morrisons, sold out. Tesco, rancid?
PM11:22am

Is the divi suddenly under threat?

Forester I suspect its because CARD has gone ex-growth in its online business so now trading at a more sensible 15P/E
BE11:22am

Well, not suddenly, but yes. Divi cover's been eroding for a while but now it looks to have rather less support post a pretty weak quarter, which has taken down consensus by about 8%.

sprout Local Morissons had a couple left but they were 'best before' 25th which seemed to be cutting it fine...
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Note that the Card Factory divi is largely a special, of the type that might not repeat and management doesn't need to blink when making the decision.

BE11:24am

Here's Peel Hunt, which downgrades.

FATDAZ have probably recalled this before but in a different life i had a notion to make a short recommendation on clinton's ( they had 5 shops in our high street) I contacted the company IR and they put on to management they were so open and helpful I couldn't bring myself to write it or pull the trigger on the idea
BE11:24am

Card Factory’s Christmas trading statement is far more than a sales update: it gives us serious concerns about the state of the industry and the earnings potential of the business. The weakness in card sales at Christmas is disappointing but worse still is the company’s view that this will persist, with non-card picking up a bit of the slack, albeit at lower gross margins. Our forecast is coming back by about 10% but the notion of a double-digit special is history for the time being and even though the competition will be in disarray, it’s hard to see forecast momentum turning here on an 18-month view. A 6% yield (inc 5p special) should be a base for the shares, but we have to admit that we got this one wrong and move to a HOLD (TP, 240p).

dfd As long as there is still a single Clintons card shop, I think Card Factory will keep expanding, and don't understand margin pressure when you only sell tat that costs about 20p to manufacture.
11:25 am
BE11:25am

This is Jonathan Prichard, who worries rather a lot about a change of tone from management.

BE11:26am

The fact that management does not believe that
this shape of sales growth is a one-off is alarming. Is the stability of the card sending market in question? Or has CARD’s range stopped resonating with the consumer? Either way it’s worrying that management thinks that any growth next year (FY19) will have to come from non-card, with the attached margin consequences. Could some of the margin pressure be mitigated with price increases on cards? Card Factory tried to raise prices in the Spring, but the customer reaction was negative and it would be surprising if a step change in pricing was attempted now. ForEx and NLW issues persist, so it’s unlikely that EBITDA will progress next year.

#REF! "A 6% yield (inc 5p special) should be a base for the shares" that statement will wind up people in our office who are adamant divi shouldn't matter in valuation
FATDAZ perhaps poundland could merge with card ?
BE11:26am

The slowdown (non-short term) in card sales
poses questions about the whole equity story. Is the 1,200 store target still appropriate? Is Getting Personal really the answer to the wider market’s channel shift? We have no doubt that Card Factory will continue to win card market share but is that of an ever-shrinking wider market? We don’t want to be too histrionic but the basis of all our enthusiasm has been the stability of the wider market. And for the first time, this is being brought into question. We can understand the Stock Market’s seemingly brutal response to the update.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

In a sense, Card Factory has parallels with WH Smith if WH Smith didn't have the travel bit to support it.

dfd I'd say the £1 shops are Card Factory's biggest competitors. Kids spending their pocket money on Fathers Day mugs etc
BE11:28am

The thing it's best known for selling is in decline so it needs to keep finding new things to fill up the floorspace, and those things are largely at a rather lower gross margin.

FATDAZ @dfd see my post above
BE11:29am

That's what we see today. Lower margin non-card products diluting the mix, hence the warning.

Fox How has CARD managed to end up with £330M in intangibles/goodwill? This gives them -ve equity if taken out of the net assets of £250M. Tangible assets only £40M?
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here's Morgan Stanley again. Geoff Ruddell, who must have about 18 notes out this morning.

BE11:30am

We believe that these downgrades will lead to questions about whether the company will be able to pay its now-customary 15p special dividend in October, leaving only the 9p base dividend. We think this would be a significant issue, given that Yield has been one of the main attractions of the Card Factory investment case
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Card Factory is trading on 14.0x Cal 2018 earnings, 11.1x EBITDA with a 5.6% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 13.1x, 8.2x and 4.0% respectively

Tom Dalgleish Would Picasso have sent cards?

And it's a "further market consolidation plus bedding down on existing acquisitions" theory.

Which is the counterpoint to all our waffling, of course. Takeaway delivery is a cozy little cartel where the top two operators buy out any rival that poses a risk to their #1 and #2 positions in the market, then the #2 operator sells out to the #1 operator.

BE11:40am

Here's Barclays.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

We are returning to OW on our analysis that JE will have strong revenue momentum into Q4 and FY18. For FY18 we calculate that revenues will surpass £710m (Bloomberg cons. £656m) due to decent growth in the marketplace, consolidation
of HungryHouse, expansion of logistics and the new surcharge. We do expect that incoming CEO Peter Plumb will recycle some excess profit into logistics and marketing, but nonetheless see upside pressure on FY18 EBITDA expectations, with HungryHouse and the service charge adding ~£30m in ’18. A further 2018 catalyst will be Brazil, where JE owns 32% of a business which on an order basis is half the size of the UK. There is a consolidation opportunity in this market, as Delivery Hero sees Brazil as non-strategic. With JE’s business having begun to turn a modest profit, we expect that investors will start to value this business separately during 2018. We therefore return to OW with a PT of 1000p, based on 30x FY19 PE (ex. Brazil and net cash).

SoS clearly need a regulator for take away food brokers - offeat?
BE11:40am

Following a revenue lull after its rebranding campaign, its current marketing has been successful and resulted in improving y/y order growth throughout the year and averaged 22% organically. This, combined with logistics, is resulting in revenue momentum and we are 3% ahead of consensus on FY17 revenues, or 11% ahead for Q4. For FY18 we are ~9% ahead and forecast ~31% growth.

Underlying revenue growth in line with our estimates; FY guidance narrowed. Boohoo’s Q3 group revenues were in line with our estimate at a cFX basis, up +93% at cFX, however thanks to a 7% FX tailwind revenues were 4% above our estimate and 8% above consensus, growing at +100% yoy (consensus +85%). Management raised full-year revenue guidance to growth of 90% (previously +80%) in line with expectations and narrowed the EBITDA margin guidance range to 9.25-9.75% (previously 9-10%). The mid-point of 9.5% is broadly in line with consensus at 9.6% (RBC 9.2%). Gross profit margins for the group fell 60bps yoy, less than consensus expectations of 100bps as investments at Boohoo were lower than expected (-140bps vs. our estimate of -400bps).

Boncoeur @PM,BE: prep/request for tomorrow's session USA CPI & retail sales, what to look for?
BE11:56am

Solid revenue growth driven by PrettyLittleThing. The strong revenue growth for the Group was driven by PrettyLittleThing (PLT). Revenues for PLT beat our estimates by 16% and consensus by 30%. However, the Boohoo brand recorded revenues 1% below consensus, up +25% vs. consensus +26% and our expectation of +28%. NastyGal revenue of £11.9m was slightly above expectations of £10m. Regionally, UK and Rest of Europe delivered growth higher than our estimates.

BE11:56am

We remain cautious on Boohoo’s mid-term margin outlook. While our EBITDA forecast for FY18e is broadly in line with consensus, we see greater risk to FY19-20e earnings expectations of 10-15%. We think the investments in price guided over the mid-term will not be offset by operating leverage and instead expect greater investments in improving the proposition to increase customer retention to be a priority for management.
